text: <@U3TR96G84> you can upload a JS File via the file manager and then copy the url path from there (by clicking on the uploaded file).
Yes indeed. But if I male changes I have To reupload it each time
The ID (big number) is the timestamp. HubSpot use this way to make a new URL every time you change the file, because those files are cached for a long time.
So It’s impossible to refer to a JS with a static URL without timestamp ?
You are right, because the URL is generated. Use file manager file would a solution, but then you need upload your file yourself after every change.
hey guys, Is there a way in hubl to offset the blog loop?
this might work `{% if loop.index > 1 %}` - source: <https://community.HubSpot.com/t5/Content-Design-Questions/Offset-starting-point-in-blog-post-list-exclude-first-post/td-p/6864>
that doesn't actually change the  query. so if you hit the 1000 posts per listing page limit you're still sol

Hey guys, I just spent 44 hours on a blog. I’m loading all of the blogs into a json variable and filtering them. When there are no filters I’m taking the recent blog @ 200 posts. Then we created some hard coded “categories” that we preload the same way. All of this is done during page build. No blog posts actually display on screen until the dom is ready, then it brings in teh first set of paginated results.
<https://www.gliffy.com/test-blog>
This isn’t “live” yet —If you click on a post it will go to the current live blog.
Clicking on those popular categories allows for the fastest way to get your blogs without having a page refresh.
And then we did a tag page also because not all blog posts will have one of those “categories”
<https://www.gliffy.com/test-blog/tag/Visual-thinking>
nice! it definitely feels fast. are you planning on adding hash support so someone could link to a category or a pagination page?
I’ve done a few similar pages to this with hubdb and we haven’t set that up yet. I feel like this will be the item that brings that around
I def want to do it, but this blog has scope creeped like crazy.
You’re awesome :slightly_smiling_face: It could be very useful
I imagine as the project gets closer to completion and I’m not working constant late nights that I’ll throw in the time and just make it happen

Sounds like you implemented it similar to what we've been doing - turning the actual blog template's all post url into a json feed- then we force it to display a design manager template instead for the lising and detail pages, allowing you to get around the 200 limit, as well as make it snappy.

We don't do this often because it takes more work and can get unnecessarily complicated when you have to care about the URLs and stuff like that. - but it works great for making product galleries/portfolios interactive maps and things like that.

Example:
<http://www.piercemfg.com/customers/new-deliveries>
Try the filters on the left and the search.
(we originally had js based pagination here too adding another layer of complexity but client decided they liked the feeling of infinite scrolling.

Also disclaimer: this was built before HubDB existed(yes it would have been easier in HubDB). Though even after HubDB we probably still would have done this the same way because it allows us to give our clients a better editing experience than HubDB does. Though this specific site we built an off- HubSpot admin portal for managing all of those trucks via the HS API.  Allowing people to have access to edit the truck information without having access to HubSpot - also allowed us to meet the clients security and processing needs.
